title: 114_s1687
content: The Act is titled the "Offshore Reinsurance Tax Fairness Act" and includes a restriction on the insurance business exception to passive foreign investment company rules. The "Offshore Reinsurance Tax Fairness Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to define a "qualifying insurance corporation" as a foreign corporation subject to tax under subchapter L with applicable insurance liabilities. The "Offshore Reinsurance Tax Fairness Act" defines a "qualifying insurance corporation" as a foreign corporation with insurance liabilities constituting more than 25% of its total assets. If the percentage is at least 10%, stock in such corporation may be treated as stock of a qualifying insurance corporation. If the percentage is at least 10%, stock in such corporation may be treated as stock of a qualifying insurance corporation. The corporation must be predominantly engaged in an insurance business, and any failure to meet the requirements must be due solely to temporary circumstances involving the insurance business. Applicable insurance liabilities include loss and loss adjustment expenses, as well as reserves. The "Offshore Reinsurance Tax Fairness Act" defines a "qualifying insurance corporation" as a foreign corporation with insurance liabilities constituting more than 25% of its total assets. Applicable insurance liabilities include loss and loss adjustment expenses, as well as reserves for life and health insurance risks and claims. The amount of liabilities should not exceed the reported amount to the insurance regulatory body or the amount required by law. The term 'applicable financial statement' in the "Offshore Reinsurance Tax Fairness Act" refers to a financial reporting statement based on accounting principles or international financial reporting standards, as determined by the Secretary. The annual statement required to be filed with the insurance regulatory body, applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2015.
